Then later I decided that was a good idea because once I started seeing what was involved I saw that with the weight problem, and the depth the painting would have to be to house the equipment, that painting was the wrong form for that to take. So I started on a sculpture. Then I went to Amsterdam to work at the Stadtlijk Museum with what was going to be a collaboration of about five artists, or six. And because I was working in sculpture, I had three weeks; we found that our ideas were so different that it was very difficult to get together and just make a piece.
[...] So I was working with the sculpture which became Oracle with the radios. And painting didn't really interest me. So in a kind of crash program of three weeks I made four pieces of sculpture and some of them quite large. One of them is about ten or twelve feet high and was very densely massed, about eight feet by five feet, and twelve feet high. That was by far the largest work. But I'm not really a sculptor in any traditional sense. I tend to work with materials that are a little heavier and put them together as practically as I can. By being a sculptor, I mean I don't weld or solder.
[...]
DS: Has it continued to interest you since then? I mean, are you likely to resume?
RR: I think the radio piece probably is the closest thing to what I'm about to do next as one can predict without knowing where one's going, because I like very much that mixture of technology and aesthetics.
DS: I was interested in what you said last time we talked, I think, about the sound having been important in shifting the focus of the audience, in a sense, in that insuring a certain movement through the exhibition ...
RR: Literally.
DS: Literally, yes.
RR: You had a sense of distance that as often as not was distorted. You had the feeling possibly of knowing where you were but where you were was lost.
DS: That's very expressive. And another thing that you had mentioned which we haven't recorded was your feeling that it was important that the sound frequencies, that the radio sources, be actual ones, not taped; and your feeling that if you had been able to tape them, it would have been rather like commercial art in that not being an actual ...
RR: Yes.
DS: Would you like to enlarge on that in any way?
RR: No, I think that just about says it. I like for the sound to be as fresh as the daily fall of the dust and rust and dirt that accumulates, which doesn't mean that one doesn't clean it off from time to time. But then that's another thing. It's an actuality of a literal insistence on the piece's operating and existing in the time situation that it's observed in. It's another one of those things trying to put off the death of the work.
DS: Yes. Did I hear you mention before that you had in mind possibly using at some time in the future a piece in which the wind might work as an actual force?
RR: Yes. I'd like to work with wind and water and plants. It sounds like it's going to be a garden, but I don't think it's going to be, but if it turns out to be a garden that may be my own sneaky way of moving out into the country. I hope I don't pick this new building out just in order to discover that what I really needed was a farm. In fact, having two dogs now is also an indication that I'm trying to get out.

fields.title: Oracle_1966_Klüver on Design & Production
fields.text:
We had worked on the technical equipment for Oracle for about three years before it was finished. We didn’t work continuously, of course, and constantly there were [always ] unsolved problems. My assistant at the laboratory, Harold Hodges, did most of the construction work. It seems to me as if I spent most of the time in endless queues in the electronic shops.  Two complete systems were built and discarded as technically unsatisfactory. The third and last system was built during the end of 1964 and the beginning of 1965.  It was installed in the last weeks before the opening on the 15th of May, 1965. My daughter was born the same day, and it was not until a week later that could I find out that the system worked better than I had expected.  The costs for the electronic components had then surpassed thirty thousand crowns,  while the labor costs were about fifteen thousand.   
At this time it goes without saying that Robert Rauschenberg’s sculpture Oracle is magnificent. It is a work of art which sums up much in his work to date and also points forward and gives a clue of what will come. When you work so closely with an artist for such a long time and have the opportunity to get discouraged many times and then become greatly surprised over the results, you appreciate [feel] more than ever the specific and the glorious way in which the artist sees. 
[...]
The difficulties that arose during the work with Oracle were maybe not so much of a technical nature (the minute we had decided on the solution the technical problems were normal), as in the collaboration with Rauschenberg.  I don’t mean that Rauschenberg in any way is difficult to work with; he is in reality of wonder of patience.  It is simply difficult for an engineer to have a conversation with an artist.  The engineer speaks slowly and with a natural hesitation.  He knows that the problem can be solved even if he can’t solve it at that moment.  He is worried about costs and needs time to experiment and to find out which materials are available.  He tries to press the artist for a more detailed description.  What is the goal ?  How strong should the amplifiers be ?  What noise level is permissible ?  Can interference between the local oscillators in the radio receivers be permitted?  What was the maximum and minimum sweep speed ?  Should it be possible for a visitor to stop at a certain station ?  How many hours should the batteries last ?  The artist works, on his side, fast and with his hands.  He works with facts and does not bind himself to theoretical details which concern the future.  In a month, in a year, maybe his attitude will be completely different from today.  He does not know the engineer’s language, he does not know the meaning of the words.  Can the engineer be trusted ? And the engineer needs complete information in order to solve the problem.  The artist wants as much freedom as is possible over the result. It is not a question of a collaboration, but rather a contractual relationship between the artist and the engineer so that in the end the engineer is only part of the total work of the artist.  The artist has to accept the engineer as he is.  
During our work with Oracle, several of these questions came up. We never arrived at any rational way of working, but I understood that we had to work, apart from the costs, with such a margin that Rauschenberg had as much freedom as possible as we worked towards the final solution.  In this way the high sound level was not present in the original specifications for the system. We did give Rauschenberg the means to change the sound level, which he wanted to keep high, something we had not foreseen but that he used. On the other hand, every amplifier was attached to a speaker of good quality.  These Rauschenberg replaced with smaller speakers of worse quality.
Oracle needed a high sound level but a relatively bad sound quality (in order to give the impression that you listened to somebody else’s radio.)  Other amusing questions appeared repeatedly:  What was a technical decision, and what was an “aesthetic” decision.  The color of the batteries, the size of the controls, the placement of the technical components were all aesthetic decisions.  It’s easy for an engineer to get trapped in what he’s doing and make decisions on the basis of what is “beautiful” instead of what is technically necessary. The engineer cannot see what he does as art.  In regards to aesthetic questions, working with Rauschenberg became very intimate.  
We’ve learned that the painting is an object among other objects in a room.  Jasper Johns shows the back side of a painting.  During a piece by John Cage we are forced to accept all sounds as an equal part of the composition. Claus Oldenburg let the people whom he uses in his happenings play themselves (in most cases the actors are not conscious of this fact.) Oldenburg writes roles in his happenings for a certain person.  In such a way the individuals’ shyness, nervousness, and sexuality become part of the happening.  
Tradition can therefore not tell us anything else but that the technical material in Oracle is an integral part of the sculpture just like the car door, the basin or the window frame.  It is impossible to treat the sound as part of the work of art and not the radios themselves. But what is the engineer’s relationship to the artist?  He uses his creativity and his experience to create something at the direction of the artist, which he obviously could not make by himself.  In the same way that Oldenburg works with and accepts the peculiarities of his actors, the artist has to accept the engineer.  The artist is a means for the engineer to arrive at a result, and the artist is equally bound to him as Michelangelo was to his marble. Oracle points to the fact that a new type of relationship is possible between the artist and the engineer, and perhaps even between the artist and the scientist.  A relationship where the artist tries to use the enormous richness of technology and science to achieve his goal.  The goal of the artist may be equally as technically complicated as building a huge accelerator or launching of  a satellite, but his goals should lie within as yet undiscovered areas of art and science:  to create new wonders, new sensual experiences, new pressures, new ways to experience each other, new ways to experience light, dark, coldness, heat; new ways to sleep, to be, and to eat.  Every engineer is conscious today of the fact that no exaggerations can describe the capacity of technology, but at the same time, the inventiveness of the engineers, how technology can be used, limited by his laziness, one-sidedness, and psychological attitude.  The relation of the engineer to the use of technology in art can today be compared to the people who insist that the only goal of art is to create a beautiful object full of a higher order.  The engineer cannot believe that the technology can be used to create disorder, but the artist can.  The artist, and only the artist, can show the engineer how technology can be used at its full capacity.  The technical part of Oracle is senseless from any engineering point of view possible.  From the radios all tuned to the AM four radio programs are re-transmitted to four other transceivers--in the same room.  The engineer can only shake his head when he hears that such a project cost almost 50,000 crowns.

fields.title: Oracle_1997_Klüver on Oracle donation
fields.text: In 1976, Oracle was sold to Mme Sào Schlumberger, who donated it to the Musée National d'Art Moderne, Paris.

fields.title: Oracle_1997_Klüver on the restoration and exhibition in 1977
fields.text:
In 1976, Oracle was sold to Mme Sao Schlumberger who donated it to the Musée National d'Art Moderne in Paris. The Sculpture was to be shown at the grand opening of the Centre Pompidou in 1977, and Hodges and I got involved again. Twelve years of wear and tear on the system and further advances in technology made it clear that the piece should be redesigned for its new location. We also saw a chance to get rid of the last remaining problems of noise and interference. With the redesign, we were now able to move the AM radios and the DC motors out of the control console and into each piece, eliminating the need to retransmit the control signals from the console. We installed what was called a "digital proportional remote radio control system" designed for remote-controlled hobby airplanes. Digital control signals for volume and sweep rate were transmitted in the 70 MHz band to servomotors in the other four pieces. Oracle had now entered the space age.
I went to Paris to install Oracle and found that Beaubourg was not a friendly place for it. The steel structure of the building acted as a Faraday cage, shielding the interior from the relatively long electromagnetic waves of the AM frequency band, so that only static could be heard on Oracle's radios. To overcome this problem, I had to install a master receiving antenna on the roof. (The only access to the roof was a thirty foot ladder from the sixth floor outside walk-way and I found myself all alone on the roof stringing the wire for the large antenna.) To get the AM signal to the gallery where Oracle was shown, I used a Jerrold Broadcast Band Amplifier, which was designed for radio showrooms and promised "you can turn on your AM radios and demonstrate the static-free humfree reception that generate sales." Hardly space-age technology, but the best I could do. What made the situation worse was that there were only 3 AM radio stations in Paris and a few audible stations from the rest of France. I had hoped to be able to tune the system to receive other European stations, but lack of time and help made this impossible in time for the opening.
Rauschenberg arrived and we worked frenetically to get Oracle going. An hour before the official opening, we plugged in the pump motor for the shower and blew all the fuses in our section of the museum. The electricians had gone home for the day and no one knew where to find the fuse box. When Minister of Culture Michel Guy and the director Pontus Hulten brought President Giscard d'Estaing and Princess Grace by, we were standing in semi-darkness. The sound from a few lonely radio stations could be heard from Oracle, and with the refrigeration coils inoperative, the frozen fat was slowly melting in Joseph Beuys' piece nearby.

fields.title: Oracle_1997_Klüver on the restoration (1979-1981)
fields.text:
I was able to plan a re-design of the system for Oracle in 1979. Engineer Ted Dillenkofer built a re-designed system for Oracle, which he and I installed in February 1979, after installing Solstice in the museum in Japan. All the electronics had been shipped to New Jersey and Ted worked with his father in his father's radio workshop to design and build the new system. Ted remembered:
...

fields.title: Oracle_1997_Klüver on the restoration (1979-1981)
fields.text: In 1981, the radios were changed to FM radios. Rauschenberg agreed to this change because the French government had opened up the FM band to independent stations. Within months, the number of stations on the FM band grew to about thirty-five with a mixture of news, classical music, popular music, and talk shows; the FM band in Paris became like the AM band in New York.

fields.title: Oracle_1997_Klüver on the restoration (1992)
fields.text: A re-design of the system in 1992 brought all the radios back into the control console and used an infrared system to transmit the resulting sound to the receivers and speakers in the other four pieces.

fields.title: Oracle_1997_Klüver on the restoration (1997)
fields.text: In 1997, Per Biorn and Toby Fitch updated the system. The five radios receiving either the AM or FM band are located in the control console in the staircase. Volume and sweep rate are controlled by potentiometers on the top of the staircase. Sweep rate is changed by using DC motors. The AM or FM band signal is then transmitted in the UHF band to receivers, amplifiers, and speakers in each of the other pieces.
